Entry.1:
& - God help us we are still here. The other night all amenities of the Scotch brigade caught fire or was set afire and at about midnight there was a noise like a demonstration at Pope’s.

It was a Sohag a few days ago that I had my first introduction to "Habhan". That is the Arabic for it; what the English is I don’t know, it is a small seed or grain that they put into the coffee which makes it delicious it is just as if a drop of Benedictine had been put in it.

Yesterday there was the most unpleasant & most impressive sandstorm that I have yet witnessed in this land of sorrow. It was like an enormous curtain of dust stretching from the earth right up to the clouds, breaking down on one, swallowing up the country as it came. There was not a breath of wind until the curtain of dust was about 20 yards away & then, in a second, one was in a swirling dusty twilight & objects more than two or three yds away were invisible. It lasted an hour & was said to be the worst they have had for six years.
Entry.2:
Still here and apparently every probability of staying here at Sohag for some time yet.

A propos of the sandstorm that I have just described I was going to add that Fortunately these visitations only occur in the daytime! But since then we have had a beauty in the middle of the night, which is certainly rare as far as our eighteen months or so experience of this country goes.

Anyway we all went to bed at the appointed time like happy little innocents, some inside the

tent & some outside. Fraser & I remained inside but we had all the Flaps up. At about 11.30 up comes a strong gusty wind, it was very hot & we welcomed it at first, then it blew stronger & stronger. I got underneath a blanket until I was nearly suffocated & the perspiration was pouring off me, then we both made a dash & let down the flaps, got about three hours sleep out of the night & got up in the morning looking just like sweeps.

The following night in 
addition
 

addition to a few of my usual bedfellows, to wit, fleas, I had another friend. I woke up in the morning with a large tick on the back of my 
right
 neck. Truly this is a charming country. It must have been very unpleasant here during the plagues, that is all I can say!
Entry.3:
Last Sunday we were stung again "Stinging" by the way is the vernacular for innoculation. On Monday we were all looking at the world & the horse lines in particular with a very jaundiced eye.

It is a most extraordinary thing but every time I come off first picket I seem to be fated to meet the drinks of the evening. Last time it was Macrae, our D.C.H., very voluble, asserting that he was in charge of the Picket & that I would ‘do him’. Last night it was Alf Boucher, the cook, who arrived just after I had got into bed, also voluble, & positively wrapped up in beer bottles, - he produced them like a conjurer form all over his person -. He paid me 10 piastres which I had lent him a few days back & insisted that I should drink a bottle with him: I demurred until he declared that he would ‘pour it

all over me"…. We parted the best of friends. This morning he came to the tent & paid me the 10 piastres over again, but to his great astonishment I returned it. I then explained, and ----- he retired from the unequal contest.

Twenty reinforcements arrived today thank goodness: of late we have been leading two & sometimes three horses apiece for exercise. The sickness here is as bad as on the Peninsular.
Entry.4:
The heat now is getting beyond all reason – 116 &degree yesterday 116 &degree today But, thank god, as yet there are

no mosquitos.

George Hamilton & two others went down to Cairo on leave yesterday. They will be drunk for forty eight house about & George will come back with a broad smile, eyes rather bloodshot & face a shade redder, but otherwise perfectly well. He told us 
that
 before he went, that he & 

Gerry Chandler were going to get a room at the National, George would be in bed one side Gerry on the other; on each table at each bedside there would be a bottle of whiskey: They would wake each other up at intervals during the night and "have a

sip’ & thus be well oblitterated when they got up!

Another instance of war economy – of time – I suppose of Late we have had to keep our candles in a bucket of water to keep the, from melting into the Jam or over our clothes as they have been known to do lately.
Entry.5:
Now that I am out here at the "palms" I may as well describe it. We often come out here nowadays more often than not, in fact, because the heat is too great for the horses standing out on the lines with no

shade; N.B. too hot for the horses not the men …. However, we have come out today to a new palmgrove it certainly is a trifle better than the last place but -. I have no doubt that just taking into consideration the main facts & overlooking all details, it appears idyllic, – the manner in which we spend our days. Take the facts. We saddle up & take two horses out to a shady grove of date palms, where we tie up our horses, eat our lunch & laze the day away with book or cards, lying full length on the shade; Then we leisurely ride back to camp in the evening. Does n’t it sound

delightful? Now take the details. It is about 95 &degree F when we start for the grove, hence we arrive these4 covered in sweat & grime & melted dubbin from off the reins: Then, having tied our horses up we spread out a saddle blanket now on the green sward as perhaps the imagination would depict in a palm grove, but on a very fine dirty black dust, which harbours every kind of offensive wog from fleas to big black beetles that defy classification.

Meanwhile the thermometer rises steadily higher & higher & one drags ones weary way around the tree

in pursuit of the somewhat inadequate shade it probably affords. The flies pester one whenever there is a lull in the scorching, dust laden, wind of "Khampsine" 

The last mentioned, by the way, is the "wind that blows for 50 days" during the better part of April & the month of May; "Khampsine" is the Arabic for 50.

Perhaps now you cease to wonder why this scrawl is filled with curses on Sohag and all things Sohagish?

Last night we had a concert which was honoured by the presence 

of "His excellency the Muller of Sohag & surrounding districts"; I was not impressed by him, he wants dieting & a strict course of Saullows, like all native bigwigs. He retired at half-time among shouts of good night. Happy New Year etc.

Charlie Cox the brigadier was also present to declare the concert well & truly open. I went there mainly to hear what he would say. I expected him at least to refer to the landing – as it was the anniversary - & possibly to let fall a few hints as to what he thought we should be doing this year: Instead of which he merely introduced

the Muller & then proceeded "I am very pleased that you are having a concert. I should like to see more of them; they keep the men together & gives them something to think about of a night. I wish you every success." Illuminating, wasn’t it? needless to say as all beer & spirits are now taboo in Sohag the concert was just about a very poor success.

I understand that the Mudir is going to give the troops a days sports, on the
Entry.6: God grant we shal’et be here!
Entry.7:
Having now nothing of import to do, think, say, or read as is too often, unfortunately, the case; a description of my immediate surroundings would not, I think, be without interest. 
For muyse
 

For myself, I am lying inside the tent writing, exuding a gentle sweat, for although it is dark & well past seven oclock it is still fiendishly hot & close. 

My friend & co-mate in exile who has his "posie" next the door amid the blessed

draught & the cursed dust, is seated at his correspondence, giving one the impression of a bird with a fountain pen – I notice that most of the time it is in his mouth – for a break, brooding in a dowry nest of note paper, composed of the numerous letters he has received 
dur
 in the course of the last five mails or so.

The next man, who sleeps next to me is just outside the tent engaged in a hot argument, to his shame be it said, for he is on first picket & should

be keeping a faithful watch & ward on the horselines. On the opposite side of the door, directly opposite to the burst of correspondence stand an imposing row of four "Goolahs" big porous earthenware jars, all empty at this hour, mute yet eloquent testimony to the eternal thirst produced by this waste of dust & dryness.

Near them lives another member who has followed the fortunes of this corps from its birth through its greatness to this present state of stagnation in which it lies. He is lying 

stretched full length, & it is a long length too – approaching six foot three – seeking a monumentary oblivion in sweaty slumber from the cares of this world, with his head on a heterogenous mass of dirty shirts, socks & handerchiefs which for the moment constitute an excellent pillow.

 A murmur of voices comes from outside the tent, for the most part indistinguishable except when some voice takes individuality as it is raised in indignant expostulation or denial. In the distant mess

tent the gramophone shrills out its well known songs & tunes most of the, heavy with age.

Over everything the hot still atmosphere hangs giving one the impression of being baked in a slow oven; all things are hot to the touch, even the candle cannot stand unprotected.

Soon, very soon now, the first post will be 
lag
 languidly blown 
by
 and one will prepare for what one calls bed with a sickening knowledge that tomorrow 
will be possibly the 
 , the night after & the night after that will all be precisely the
Entry.8:
wer
 trivial round of wearying monotony.
Entry.9:
"The happiest day of all the glad new year" Most emphatically NO!

However I think somehow that things are looking up a little. I expect to be in Tal el Kabir shortly & then "Hey, for the Persian Gulf".

Truly things are becoming unbearable here now.

Mice wake us up from our sleep by running over our faces. The other night I caught

a centipede crawling up my leg & Frances caught a tarantula with the same object on him. They are beastly things, however ‘de mortuis’.

Rumour is getting busy at last down at the brigade forge, It is the Press bureau for the brigade. The Smiths swear & sweat working to the tunes of "Jesus loves me; I don’t think", 
usually no
 They seem to work better to that tune than to any other.
Entry.10:
We are supposed to be moving shortly – I hope to goodness that it comes off – and mean while I am 
supposed
 somewhat exercised as to how I am going to carry all my stuff.

We are supposed to be travelling light i.e. one is permitted to carry what one can get on one’s horse & a few things rolled up in ones blankets. I have managed – by means of honeyed words in the ears of one of the drivers of the 
drill
 transport wagons to bring along with me a small infantry pack also. But now

it will require some ingenuity to get all my stuff along on this next move. I have a saddle and bridle, grooming kit, heel peg, ‘toggle rope’, water bucket, mess tin, feed bag, great coat, & water proof cover for my saddle & a chain bead rope – all that poor unfortunate "Bernard" M.C. Evan’s ch.g., will have to carry . In addition I have two blankets Two prs of breeches, two pairs of trousers Two coats, one suit of pyjamas, two prs of boots, a sun helmet, a slouch hat, a cap. Three shirts, two singlets, 6 or 8 prs of socks, one cardigan jacket, one haversack, water bottle & numerous small trifles such as a towel

shaving gear, pipes & tobacco, hair brush etc etc. Yea God’s & I am travelling light! Yet one thing is certain, it will all go. I think I could hold my own with mother at packing now & the more 
comf
 comfortable it is.
Entry.11:
We were delayed from moving last week for some reason or other, but we are going for certain this week. I think on Sunday for I have just seen the orders from Headquarters.

We are going down to Kantara which is right on the Canal.
Entry.12:
tomorrow there will be alarms & excursions I suppose & poor old Jackie – our 8 hr – won’t know whether he is on his head or his heels and the hard workers will do all the work while the pointers take a holiday & do nothing; Oh! I could map out the programmes of the next few days as accurately as if they were already past! – But I had better not anticipate. Let it suffice to say that we are at least about to shake from off our perspirings feet the thrice accursed dust of Sohag.

"Hill 40"
Entry.13:
Now we are quite the other side of Egypt altogether, but I had better record how we got here first.

We managed to get all our horses & stuff on board the train at Sohag by about 9.30 on Sunday night.

I provided a very fitting climax to my unpleasant stay at Sohag by losing my money belt with a fiver in it just before we left. 

We spent an uncomfortable night in the train. I slept in the alley way being continually

woken up by the mud 
from
 dropping on my face from the boots of the man sleeping on the seat above me.

We stopped however at Beue Sueff & Zagazig to water & feed so there was ample time to wash.

We arrived at Kantara at about 6 in the evening & were encamped about 15 minutes walk from the canal.

Then I experienced two of the hottest days of my young & tender life; 124 &degree F in the shade with a hot wind that feels like a blast from the biggest furnace

God ever made, one simply dried up it was impossible to sweat – but it defies description.

Then yesterday morning at 2 oclock we crossed the canal by the pontoon bridge & rode out to this spot – "Hill 40" it is seven miles from the canal. There is a limestone road running out here also a railway which is nearly standard 
gage
 guage & there is a meagre supply of water laid on: so all things considered we are very well off. Though 
yest
 yesterday we had to wait an hour

and 40 minutes to water our horses 
which by the way is pure cruelty in this heat
 

The last two days have been beautifully cool owing to a North Wind but God help us if we get a South wind.

The transport has remained at Kantara 
as
 further than this all transport work is done by camels & I should not be surprised if they gave us Camels in place of horses.
Entry.14:
I am unfortunately, today on day picquet so I am going to sneak enough time while the horses are

feeding to write a little more about this spot. Our Division the HM. is holding 
of
 from 
here 
 the sea to Tsmailiah: But I can of course only describe the defences or the actual way by which we came out. Having crossed the pontoon bridge over the Canal, imagine in front of you a fairly good limestone road on both sides of which are encamped battalion after battalion of infantry. This continues for perhaps, a mile and half, then, about half a mile after the last of the tents, we come to a system of trenches running as far as the eye can see north & 

south from the road which, of course runs about almost due East.

The Trenches have of course their usual complement of murderous barbed wire 

After this the road leads away out into the distance like a great white snake wriggling in & out of the dull neutral tinted sand dunes, occasionally one passes a salt lake two or three feet deep – for it is very little above sea level, - but there are no more signs of camp life until one reached "Hill 40" which as its name implies is nothing more than a slight mound.

As I declared I would, I managed to carry all my clothes etc with me to Kantara, but now I am really travelling light as I left everything there except one blanket, one shirt, & 3 prs of socks.

Last night I had a severe shock, I dined off some boiled meat, both cold & greasy, & found to me horror & astonishment that I was enjoying it immensely! Truly its time I returned to civilisation.

"Romani"

End of May

We have moved out from "Hill 40" and are now 20 miles further out, making the distance from the canal in all about 30 miles & quite far enough too.

We started at 3 o’clock yesterday morning with just as much as we could pack on the saddle.

We first traversed a sandy ground interspersed with large & frequent hummocks of desert vegetation, then , descending a steep bank, came out on a species of swampy marsh – evidently one of these salt lakes just dried

up – our last stage was across pure sand, heaped into every shape & position, terrible going for the horses but really rather a pretty sight to see the long column of horseman climbing up & down 
in sand of
 in & out amongst the enormous orange coloured sand dunes set off by the deep blue of the sky. In fact read any decent fiction books’ account of the Azure sky, golden sands etc & you have it. there were only these two main colours, as there was no vegetation or trees.

The horses got not water until we

arrived here at about 10 oclock so they had a pretty poor time; mine kept on trying to bite into my water bottle.

Now we encamped in a tiny little palm grove with enormous sand dunes two sides of us & underfoot brackish water about two feet down. A very fair place for a desert camp.

There is a railway out here so we don’t do so badly for food but all our drinking water comes by train so it will be very scarce if we have a heat wave.

However at present we are very comfortable, we have a tent pitched under a palm tree: At the side there is a well for washing water made by the simple process of digging down a few feet & sinking a punctured kerosene tin; 
on a
 while on a neighbouring tree hangs our home-made shower bath also constructed out of the ubiquitous kerosene tin which one fills, 
hulls
 hauls up to a branch by means of a pulley & dashes underneath "in pures naturalibus" as Mr Hinchcliffe says. At the tent door stands our kitchen range, yet another kerosene

also
 tin, also ‘treated’, by means of which we make cocoa o’nights for the stomachs sake.

Truly a nomads’ paradise.

The evening of the same day.

I might have known some judgement would have been visited on me for the above lines of my satisfaction. Now DAMN all kerosene tins, tins of every kind, both big & small, round & hollow, but most eternal and everlasting be the damnation of the particular tin on which this evening I cut two of my right hand fingers. After which to crown my disgust a miserable

beast of a horse kicked me on the shin. Of for the humdrum days of peace!

They can’t leave us alone even here after dragging us out 30 miles into the desert. Tomorrow night – I believe – we are going out for a two or three day’s "stunt" with the 
alledged
 alleged object of rounding up an out post of Johnny Turk,

After that Rumour says that we are going to leave here & embark for somewhere she apparently does not know where.

"Dubarbos"
Entry.15:
The great "Stunt" is on! We left our pleasant little retreat at Romaneh at 10 pm. It was a fine sight to see the start lines of horsemen passing by – we had to wait for a brigade to go by – they looked very well passing by, rather impressive in fact, as they stretched as far as 
you
 could be seen in both directions, always moving past without a sound or a light; In short it gave one the impression of attending a phantom review. We started out shortly afterwards & getting about 5 miles out of camp we lagged behind a little for some reason or other & the result

 

was that we lost sight of the preceding unit & lost ourselves in the open desert! The O.C. for about an hour & half asserted that he was sure that it was "straight on" & confidently led us in circles – any ass could have told that we were circling by watching the stars –. Finally they 
ligh
 lit sufficient matches to 
wait
 cause the annihilation of an Army Corps had any happened to see them; and by this means took a bearing with a compass & found to their astonishment that instead of East, we were going due South. Thereupon they retired from the unequal contest & we

lay down where we were until dawn & thus arrived at our bivouac here at midday instead of early morning. Tonight if all goes well we should get to grips. It is intended to be a surprise but I think the turks knew all about it before we started, anyway they would be very slow if they didn’t. We go out again tonight & return here all being well tomorrow night. So now I am going to slumber.

"Dubarbos"

7.15 pm
Entry.16:
We move at 8.30 pm tonight, if all goes well we should round up the Turks at about 4 a.m. & get back here again for our evening meal.

That at any rate is the idea. How it will pan out we shall see. Promises to be a chilly night; there is a North wind off the meditearanean, will be really cold in the early hours. It will be somewhat of a strain keeping awake tonight as we were travelling all last night with the exception of an hour and a half & then the sandflies had a huge meal.

It will be hell for anyone who gets wounded badly as they have to travel by camel for over 30 miles and it is not very comfortable for an ordinary rider.

I must light up my last pipe now as it grows dark & "no smoking after dark".

About 11 pm

Halted beside some evil smelling marsh in order.

About 2.30 am

Halted again. always halting now. The sandflies are awful. Nothing doing yet though it is still dark as you can see from my writing.

Some miles beyond Bir el Abd" about 5. 30 am 

Well the darkness is over & the sun us up and not a shot fired!

"Sic transit Gloria Belle"

However there is or has been some excitement with the other column. shots can be heard in the distance. We shall probably go over there later. The only result of these glorious proceedings is that we are all as cold as charity. I, at any rate have had about two hours sleep the last two nights & nearly fell out of the saddle several times last night by dropping off to sleep.

"Romaneh" Next Day
Entry.17:
The "stunt" is now over thank goodness and we are now back in Camp at Romaneh. however to continue

my recitation of events. After writing the above I went over to this ridge & there discovered that half an hour before I arrived the New Zealanders had come upon a camp of about 2-300 turks & "shots were exchanged" but owing doubtless to the 
sun being
 dawn having already broken, the enemy had almost all got away. The aeroplanes of ours did some very pretty work as they were getting away diving 
go
 down to about 200 feet, dropping bombs, & as she rose again letting go with the machine gun in her tail. The whole scrap gave me the impression of a little comedy perfectly staged with us in the boxes

The total result was that we had two of our men slightly wounded and captured – don’t laugh – one Turk (untouched) our nondescript dressed in what looked like, & I believe was, an old Irish dress frock coat, bright green with age (wounded in three places).

One old woman (about 100 & anything) one "wallad"

Two very dirty looking 
girls
 "biuts" one child in arms (not the military issue). Also we buried about six stiff’uns. Then we left the place at about 8 oclock, leaving the camp – comprised of palm leaf huts – in flames.

But it was a terribly large net to catch such small fish. 

We were composed of: - one General with staff complete. Two Brigades of mounted men – roughly 1500 men – one big 18 pde gun. Two Ambulances and nearly a thousand camels bringing water, stores & equipment.

I think the trouble lay in the fact that since the aeroplane’s last report – at sundown- the enemy had shifted about 4 miles further than Bir el Abd where we had proposed to surprise them, the result being that we came on them half an hour too

late; the dawn, as I have said having already broken.

We left Bit el Abd at about 8 oclock got back to our temporary camp – the place where I commenced this lengthy despatch, I don’t know its name – about 3 oclock; drew fodder & rations; stopped at "Oghratina" for tea; then proceeded back arriving here at about 1.30 on the morning of
Entry.18:
(today), having sustained one casualty – a horse, which was shot as its leg was broken by an exceedingly well-directed kick 
on the
 as we 
coming
 came home – 

It was exceedingly fortunate for us that we came straight home

for at about 6.30 thin morning a few hours only after our arrival an enemy aeroplane came over the camp, having evidently followed us up, and dropped seven bombs on the camp, doing a lot of damage in fact killing 4 men of the
Entry.19:
Light Horse & wounding nearly 20 more 6 of which have already died from wounds, 2 officers and killing or disabling about 30 to 40 horses. Thus it was extremely fortunate that 
we
 the aeroplane did not catch the column on the march. 

Of such a kind then is one of these "stunts". I feel an overwhelming sympathy with, & pity for Poor old Xenophon

such my
 My main impression of it is an intense desire, sometimes for water, sometimes for tobacco; and above all an 
overwhleming
 overwhelming sense of irritable sleepiness inable to be appeased: for from 6 oclock on Monday morning until 2 oclock Thursday morning I only had four hours of sleep altogether.

My only comment is "God forbid that we shall go on many more of these obnoxious affairs"

As you see I tried taking my diary with me and jotting down things as they occurred, but it is not much good as one has not time, inclination or enough light.
Entry.20:
A disaster has overtaken us! We have been incontinently booted out of our pleasant little retreat beneath the Palm trees, consequent upon the arrival of the rest of the corps to this district. The place in which we are now situated is on the top of a hill on the bare sand. 

By the way, the aeroplane reports that there are thirteen Turkish dead lying 
dead
 where we had the scrap beyond Bir el Abd, so we did not do so badly after all. I have drawn a map of the district below.

Romaneh – The district in which our troops have a standing camp. Extends over a large area consisting of a number of Palm grove

Katieh – A well of good water & a few Palm groves A Regt. of Yeomanry were surrounded here in
Entry.21:
Er Arbah – Salt water marsh & grove.

Oghratina – Single big Palm grove & wells backed by big sand dune. A whole Squadron of the Yeomanry wiped out here one man surviving same time as Katieh

Dubarbos – Palm grove & wells in which we made our temporary base for the advance on

 Birelabd – which is a small grove with old well & full of some herb which when crushed gives out a strong musk like scent very noticeable in the dark. 

There was an aeroplane scare this morning – reported about seven miles away by an outpost – Everyone scattered all over the desert with his horse & then , of course, being ready for it, the cussed plane did not turn up. 

Last night some stuff was found missing from the QM store. The result was that 
the
 two "officers" in that beautifully, tactful & gentlemanly way some of these people have immediately without a word of explanation to apology searched everyone’s kit!. I, & everyone else too, was furiously angry but afterwards it occurred

to me that it was so like the unfortunate parlour maid having her boxes searched after a jewel robbery. However – enough.

I was interested to find out that during the stunt we traversed one of the oldest roads in the world, in fact I did not know it until I was told afterwards, but 
app
 apparently Pharoah took that road then Napolean to Aire
Entry.22:
Just now I am engaged in guarding our water supply – a futile business, largely the outcome of the stealing episode. However I am on first shift and there is a good moon so it is not so bad. In fact it is mainly on these occasions alone that one has time for ant protracted meditation in this chequered existence.

There is one redeeming feature about Egypt – the nights are wonderful. 

Here we are 30 miles odd East of the Suez Canal in the bare desert, at night there is

not a sound, save the occasional bark of a desert jackal or dingo, both of which seem to abound in all parts of the desert both eastern & western.

Wild Rumours have been rearing their fantastic heads of late – Kitchener & his staff have been drowned off the Orkneys – I hope that’s not true. 31,000 Turks in Mesopotamia & 25,000 Germans at Verdun have surrendered – another – Verdun has fallen, & so on & so forth; one hardly knows – or cares much now – what to think

Just had a visit from our new Q M. Sgt. to see how much water we had; he is a shrewd lad, and successfully carried through a rather amusing and, by all accounts, a somewhat unscrupulous intrigue to obtain this high office. Well, good luck to him, if you don’t look after yourself in this outfit you may be quite certain of one thing, namely, no one else will do so.

I have just lit my curved pipe, which ought to carry me through until 10 oclock, when I rout out my relief who

will also sit idly in front of the water for three hours a eloquent, I may say, an extremely eloquent witness to the fact that he is being sacrificed to Red Tape.

The mosquitoes & sandflies are beginning to make their presence distinctly felt, so I think I will keep on the move.
Entry.23:
Just back from another of these cussed ‘stunts’. For once it is a novel & interesting experience but after that they become a succession of monotonous & extremely tyring discomforts.

This time we made an excursion right off the right hand bottom corner of the map, or at least of the map that H.Q. supplies.

We went out at 3 am on Saturday morning & went direct to Sarghia (vids map.) reaching that delectable spot at about 10 oclock. We set out from there at 8 pm intending to travel South East to Bir el Bayud which was to have been reached at dawn. We were however at 1 oclock delayed by a thick fog until 5 oclock & finally got to our destination about 9 oclock. There we found a small outpost in possession of a ridge & a long range duel

ensued in a desultory manner for about 3 hrs: the only casualties - on our side at any rate – being two horses slightly wounded by strays.

I myself heard three bullets whistle over, the first I have heard since Anzac, - I was forgetting that there was a war on.

The whole thing was very funny Officers would ride up smiling & rubbing their hands "there is a beautiful little engagement going on up on the hill there" "Anybody hit yet?" " Oh no not when I left" It seems so incongruous after

the peninsular.

At about 1 o’clock, having attempted to water our horses, without much success as the water was black & stank – full of H2S I think – we filled in all their wells & departed in peace, reached Oghratina for ten and got back here soon after midnight – early this morning in fact - .

The Joke is that while nearly everyone was out of Camp – except guards of course – two Turkish ‘planes came over & peppered it with machine guns.

These excursions into the unknown are a great strain as one gets little

enough sleep at ordinary times with having to "stand to" at 3.30 am.

We are, in fact, leading a cocky’s life at present, up at 3.30 every morning & taking our horses off the lines until daybreak: what for, goodness only knows; planes or an attack presumably, but even then, - However who am I to enquire into the dispensation of Red Tape?

During the last few days several thousand infantry have arrived out here, and are now busily employed constructing redoubts & trenches, apparently

making, in fact, a first Line of defence. Whereat we rejoice greatly as it points to our leaving here, as the men at Divisional H Qs declare that the scheme out here is not an advance but merely an offensive to keep the Turks out of gunshot of the Canal.
Entry.24:
when the line of trenches & redoubts are completed & they have finished the 6’ pipe of water they are running out here, we shall be practically useless unless we have to advance further out which is unlikely, being well out of range of the casualties.

Then there seems to be a chance that we shall be withdrawn from here and shall go to Europe. That is the current rumour, & some hardy liars (I think) even declare that the
Entry.25:
Regt has already gone.

Then we shall have no more of these unpleasant stunts, the gentle reader has (probably) no idea how unpleasant it is to go riding on & on over endless sand using all one’s muscular energy in a futile attempt to keep ones eyes open.
Entry.26:
We have had very dull days lately nothing at all has happened, no aeroplanes, not even a rumour

Some of the fellows had to go out on another stunt last Wednesday but luckily I escaped that as Bernard has a sore back – no fault of mine they made us take him out last time when his back was beginning to be rubbed.

However I am very glad I did not go as they went out as far as Bir el Abd but never saw a turk not fired a shot, so there was not much in it.

I am afraid that Bernard will have to be sent back to the remount depot as he is as poor as a crow & in addition to 

the sore on his back, there is something wrong with the skin or muscle just behind his withers anyway he is very tender there. Will take him to the Vet tomorrow & find out.

Of Late we have had some tobacco & Red cross Gift stuff doled out to us in one packet of cigarettes there was the address of the sender, and I have just written to her. She took my fancy because of instead of signing herself Miss L Stoggs etc as most of them did she wrote her Christian name Lillian Horner I like "Lillian" so I wrote an

attempt at an amusing letter just to see if the good (girl,) (Lady) (old woman) will answer it.
Entry.27:
They are springing the Sohag Stunt on us again now & we have to take our horses down to the palm trees for shade. Which is a miserable business because we cannot sleep in comfort.

I am getting very tired of Romaneh now we have not seen a paper since we left Sohag and we not now even know if Fathy Pasha still takes the "Iftar" with the sultan everyday as he used to do, I think it must be a patent medicine or

something…

The chief topic of interest in camp now seems to be when our worthy S.M. is going to put on a new shirt. Controversy waxes strong on the subject and, I believe bets have been laid. He is reported to have worn the same shirt continuously during our stay at Sohag, but at Kantarah, amidst public rejoicing, he blossomed forth into a white singlet. It was and indiscreet step for white shows up the dirt rather markedly and now – after a month – it had distinctly lost its white & shining lustre.

Yesterday about seven oclock in the morning about 10 or more ‘Planes went over to raid El Arish the Turkish base. They dropped 88 bombs & did a lot of damage & lost three of our ‘Planes. So now we are expecting reprisals though no Turkish ‘planes have put in an appearance up to now.
Entry.28:
Nuthing’ doin’ in the Turkish Planes business yet, I think our people must have put them out of action.

Down in the palms again today Been occupied sewing a new corner onto my haversack with the

aid of a prodigiously large needle & a piece of an old nose bag. It is now finished & may be described as being a very stout & reliable piece of work, though hardly calculated, perhaps to enhance the already somewhat faded beauties of the haversack. There has been a miscalculation somewhere & the result is one corner is larger than the other; something like this- :

I am, however, beginning to think that with Ecclesiastes in that "Vanitas Vanitatum!" "Omnia Vanitas!"

A Rumour is running rife (if they do run like that – I forget) concerning a stunt tonight at midnight However as Bernard is still undisposed it is unlikely that I shall go out.
Entry.29:
I was right, our Intelligence Bureau was correct even if its methods were somewhat devious. The Stunters started at 3 oclock this morning, I, I am thankful to say, not among the number.

Iron mongery in the Beef!! 

A certain hesitation & circumspection

is noticeable now among those who eat Bully beef when masticating that wholly delightful food. This is the result of a morning read out in general orders to beware of small steel hooks in the beef. Fancy one’s stomach peopled with small steel hooks!

As I heard someone say ‘what tales to tell after the war "Ah Thems’ was the days, Bill, when I’ad four gross 
of
 o’steel ‘ooks took out o’ me innards"!

The Hun is a delightful fighter. Of course if is possible it is an economy scheme on the part of the military authorities for

the conservation of tinned meat.

Of Late there has been a terrible shortage of jam in our mess, and proposals for the holding of a Jam Ramadan have been seriously discussed.

However now we come out to these palm trees every day the problem has not been so pressing.

Nowadays our needs are very small give us a little shade, a blanket & some tea: Everyday now we string our way down to these palms, tie up our horses, spread out our saddle blanket much as the moslem puts down his

prayer carpet. And there we lie stretched in attitudes of hardly graceful ease, until the clarion call of Ie-e-e-e-e-o. breaks in our eager ears; then with a clink & clank, as of a multitude of mugs being grabbed, each walks or runs according to his disposition, the heat, and the state of his throat, to the place by the fire where one uttering strange cries & brandishing a pannikin dispenses the amber fluid. 

The rest is silence, save for the gnashing of teeth and occasional irrelevant remarks

anent the mystery of the position of the opener.

Follow sighs of repletion & a hot controversy on the identity of him who shall bury, cause to be buried, or otherwise makes away with the fearful array of empty tins drawn up around our blankets, given testimonials to the rapacity of man & members of one mess in particular.
Entry.30:
The heat has increased noticeably since we first arrived here. Late last night our noble fighters

for the freedom of Europe returned home not having heard a shot fired & being kept out there a day extra in order to bring back one of our aeroplanes they discovered. This is one of the three we lost in the last raid on El Arish.

It appears very much as if we are not going to be relieved here for another month according to the common report. How the horses will stick another month I don’t know they are all terribly ticked up now: It means a lot of deaths if this is so. We have ten horses over in the
Entry.31:
Corps lines which is nearly 10% & the Regiments are nearly as bad.

We had Macrae on the go last night telling us his experiences on the Tramways. It is every bit as good as reading Kipling to listen to him. He told us that different types of passengers From the regular city man who has the exact fare always ready to the chatty young thing that has to search their vanity bags to get to her ‘holy of holies’ purse to extract the necessary ‘dena’ How a drunk deposited the change of half a soo on the seat

beside him & departed , happy in the belief that it was in his trouser pocket.

How he stood on a ‘tray bit’ on George St to Waverley ringing the bell with the wrong foot before he could pick up it; & so on & so forth. He kept it up for two solid hours & kept us laughing all the time.
Entry.32:
Another aeroplane scare this morning. there was, however, nothing doing as one of our ‘planes came up & shooed him off. It was just before breakfast at about half past six, we all took out our

horses & scattered, stayed out about 10 minutes & then proceeded to break our fast, one or two fellows who evidently take these scares somewhat too seriously didn’t get back until after breakfast affording great merriment to the crowd.

The evenings from five oclock now are the only parts of the days worth living for, they are really quite nice. I remember about this time last year we had the nicest weather I have ever experienced cruising amongst the Aegean Isles on the SS Galeka. I remember one morning in

particular about 7 oclock we were passing a beautiful island covered in varying shades of green vegetation; it seemed to rise steeply from the sea until the peaks were obscured by fleecy white clouds. I was sitting right up in the bows of the boat lost in admiration & rhapsodising over the blue sea & green island golden sunshine etc when up comes "Dug" Brownfield who is most distinctly of the earth, earthy, with the request that I should help him transport a corpse to the stern of the boat – we were carrying wounded to

Alexandria - , which was an unpleasant job as the man having died in the cabin – the "Galeka" was not a hospital boat – his unfortunate lay had to be up ended like a milkcan several times before we could get it out on deck.

"Dug" – he left us on the Peninsular in Australia now – was particularly adapted for that job. He was emphatically not a sentimentalist He would shout to me. ‘Er give us a ‘and to carry a stiff ‘un aft". Then he would throw down his cap – it was as far as his respect for the ‘stiff’un’ went, otherwise he was

eminently businesslike – Then off we would stagger with our burden, Dug swearing, spitting, sniffing & saying with brutal directives "Gawd ‘e don’t ‘arf pong do ‘e? It would have been pathetic has one had time to realise it, for such was in many cases the sole requiem for a Hero of Anzac.
Entry.33:
Just been watching a most thrilling sight while it lasted. About 8.15 we had another Aeroplane scare & waited about 20 minutes until our ‘plane – which had evidently been telephoned

for from Kantara – arrived. He sighted the Taube & a very pretty piece of manoeuvring took place in which which our plane got the position on top, & 

then the two ‘planes went at it with machine guns. This was at about 1500 feet almost directly above our heads, & there was the added excitement in that at any moment the Turk might take it into his head to drop a bomb on us.

However, he did not fortunately & after a few rounds he made for home with our ‘plane close on him. As far as we could

see, he got away as his 
machin
 machine secured faster than ours. Ours has not yet come back so we don’t know as yet what happened. However it was as good as having your shirt on the favourite in the last race while it lasted.
Entry.34:
‘16

From all accounts Johnny was too good for our plane the other day as they say that our plane had to come down at Katia and I think that is right because a ‘plane riddled with bullets was taken back to Kantara by the train yesterday. Johnny was

reported from Oghratina, flying very shakily. I don’t think he got quite home either.

At 2 oclock this morning half the corps went out on a stunt I was in the lucky half & stayed at home. I should have anyway probably as Bernards back is hardly right yet.
Entry.35:
The latest is second hand from the mouth of the Major himself that we are going to England at the end of this month – I wonder. During the last few days there has been an extraordinary increase in the number of crickets

here, so much so, indeed that they are becoming quite a plague. They are everywhere, in ones blanket, spare clothes, the food box, absolutely everywhere. They are not very prepossessing creatures either being dead black about the size of the ordinary black beetle & kick up a most unholy noise, just like the cicadas in Australia.

I wish we could have dugouts instead of tents here. The dugout is a much superior dwelling for the nubile private. In a tent there are usually seven or eight while in a dugout one seldom has

more than one companion, in fact it lies with the occupant as to the caracter & number of 
your
 his companions, & his doings & the disposition of his goods & chattels concerns the occupants alone not the OS OO & OC as is the case when living in tents.

The dugout, in short, may be described as being the height of luxury for the proletariat of Military society.

After the Dugout comes the Tent, which is neither so comfortable nor so untravelled an existence as the former

 After the Tent comes the most uncomfortable mode of existence of the lot namely the Trooper : or Rather I should say that these are two degrees of discomfort the Long distance Trooper carrying a Unit of number of units; here at least one has ones 18" hammock swinging space which, if negligable, is at least ones own. 

Secondly, the short distance trooper carrying details, here one reaches the absolute limit. The trip is behaps only a week or few days hence the boat has been many times before & as a result is probably
